speaker: BING CROSBY
line: Have yourself a merry little Christmas let yourself be light From now on, our troubles will be out of sight....

speaker: MULDER
line: I almost gave up on you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sorry. Checkout lines were worse than rush hour on the 95. If I heard "Silent Night" one more time I was going to start taking hostages. What are we doing here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Stakeout.

speaker: SCULLY
line: On Christmas Eve?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's an important date.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No kidding.

speaker: MULDER
line: Important to why we're here. Why don't you turn off your car and I'll fill you in on the details.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I've got wrapping to do. It's the night before Christmas.

speaker: BING CROSBY
line: Here we are...

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh.

speaker: BING CROSBY
line: Happy golden days of yore...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let's hear it. Give me the details.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, if you've got Christmas stuff to do I don't want to... you know...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I drove all the way out here. I might as well know why. Right?

speaker: MULDER
line: I just thought you'd be more... curious.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who lives in the house?

speaker: MULDER
line: No one.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then who are we staking out?

speaker: MULDER
line: The former occupants.

speaker: SCULLY
line: They've come back?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's the story.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I see. The dark, gothic manor the, uh, omnipresent low fog hugging the thicket of overgrowth. Wait-- is that a hound I hear baying out on the moors?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. Actually that was a left cheek sneak.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, tell me you didn't call me out here on Christmas Eve to go ghost busting with you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Technically speaking they're called apparitions.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, call it what you want. I've got holiday cheer to spread.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll make it fast. I'll just give you the details.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay.

speaker: MULDER
line: Christmas, 1917. It was a time of dark, dark despair. American soldiers were dying at an ungodly rate in a war-torn Europe while at home, a deadly strain of the flu virus attacked young and old alike. Tragedy was a visitor on every doorstep while a creeping hopelessness set in with every man, woman and child. It was a time of dark, dark despair.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You said that.

speaker: MULDER
line: But here at 1501 Larkspur Lane for a pair of star-crossed lovers tragedy came not from war or pestilence-- not by the boot heel or the bombardier-- but by their own innocent hand.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Go on.

speaker: MULDER
line: His name was Maurice. He was a... a brooding but heroic young man beloved of Lyda, a sublime beauty with a light that seemed to follow her wherever she went. They were likened to two angels descended from heaven whom the gods could not protect from the horrors being visited upon this cold, grey earth.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And what happened to them?

speaker: MULDER
line: Driven by a tragic fear of separation they forged a lovers' pact so that they might spend eternity together and not spend one precious Christmas apart.

speaker: SCULLY
line: They killed themselves?

speaker: MULDER
line: And their ghosts haunt this house every Christmas Eve.

speaker: MULDER
line: I just gave myself chills.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a good story, Mulder... And very well told but I don't believe it.

speaker: MULDER
line: You don't believe in ghosts?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That surprises you?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well... Yeah. I thought everybody believed in ghosts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, if it were any other night I might let you talk me into it but the halls are decked and I got to go.

speaker: MULDER
line: My best to the family.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you doing? Mulder, don't you have somewhere to be?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm just going to take a look.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not going to do it. My New Year's resolution.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Change your mind?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did you take my car keys?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Come on, Mulder. Don't kid around.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why would I take your car keys?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe you, uh... Maybe you grabbed them by mistake.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe it was a ghost.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a cold wind.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There must be a window open upstairs. You know, the weather report said that there was an 80 percent chance of rain maybe even a... maybe even a white Christmas.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think the spirits are among us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, will you quit trying to scare me and help me get these doors open.

speaker: MULDER
line: Sounds like there's somebody walking around upstairs.

speaker: MULDER
line: There. You hear that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I really have to go.

speaker: MULDER
line: There's nothing to be afraid of.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not afraid, okay?

speaker: MULDER
line: Ghosts are benevolent entities.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mostly.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You are not scaring me, Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, I really have to get home.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Shh! What was that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: These are tricks that the mind plays. They are ingrained cliches from a thousand different horror films. When we hear a sound, we get a chill. We-we see a shadow and we allow ourselves to imagine something that an otherwise rational person would discount out of hand. The whole... Mulder...? The whole idea of a benevolent entity fits perfectly with what I'm saying. That a spirit would materialize or return for no other purpose than to show itself is silly and ridiculous. I mean, what it really shows is how silly and ridiculous we have become in believing such things. I mean, that... That we can ignore all natural laws about the corporeal body- that-that we witness these spirits clad in-in their own shabby outfits with the same old haircuts and hairstyles never aging, never... Never in search of more comfortable surroundings-- it actually ends up saying more about the living than it does about the dead.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I mean, Mulder, it doesn't take an advanced degree in psychology to understand the... the unconscious yearnings that these imaginings satisfy. You know, the-the longing for immortality the hope that there is something beyond this mortal coil- that-that we might never be long without our loved ones. I mean, these are powerful, powerful desires. I mean, they're the very essence of what make us human. The very essence of Christmas, actually.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tell me you're not afraid.

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right. I'm afraid... but it's an irrational fear.

speaker: MULDER
line: I got your back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, did it occur to you that there aren't ghosts here but that somebody actually might be living in this house?

speaker: MULDER
line: No one lives here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But when you and I were sitting out in the car there was not a light on. And look at this.

speaker: MULDER
line: Must have been some kind of electrical surge.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, did you happen to notice the clock downstairs is keeping perfect time?

speaker: MULDER
line: Is it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: And how do you explain that?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This fire has just gone out.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't look so disappointed.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why would anyone want to live in a cursed house?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it's not enough that it's haunted? It has to be cursed?

speaker: MULDER
line: Every couple that's ever lived here has met a tragic end. Three double murders in the last 80 years. All on Christmas Eve.

speaker: MULDER
line: Whoa... There's that sound again

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's not funny!

speaker: MULDER
line: I think there's a hiding space under the floorboards.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you going to do?

speaker: MULDER
line: There may be somebody trapped under there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, don't.

speaker: MULDER
line: I got to get them out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Not now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, you have a gun, right? Rationally, you've been in much more dangerous situations.

speaker: MULDER
line: I was half right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, my God.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully... Look at this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's a woman.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, it looks like they were shot to death.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know what's weird?

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, she's wearing my outfit.

speaker: MULDER
line: How embarrassing.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, well, you know what? He's wearing yours.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh... Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's us.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is the same room.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right. I'm beginning to... Get this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You go through that door and I...

speaker: MULDER
line: I should come out... This door.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully. Scully, can you hear me?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey! Who are you?

speaker: MAURICE
line: That's a question I should be asking being this is my house you're standing in. This isn't one of those home invasions, is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Good. Would you like me to show you the door?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's very funny.

speaker: MAURICE
line: I wasn't making a joke.

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you looked at the door?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Uh-huh, I'm looking at it now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Tell me what you see.

speaker: MAURICE
line: I see a door with the lock shot off it. You going to pay for that?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a door with a brick wall behind it.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Okay, sure.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're playing tricks on me.

speaker: MAURICE
line: If I am, I'm sorry but I don't know any tricks.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah? That's a trick in itself, isn't it? You've been playing tricks on us since we got here.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Am I to take it we're not alone?

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah, that's very funny coming from a ghost.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Yeah, oh... the gun fooled me a little at first. You're a ghost hunter, huh? And you think I'm a ghost, huh? I've seen a lot of strange folks coming around here with a lot of strange equipment but I think you must be the first I've seen come armed.

speaker: MULDER
line: Strange folks?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: MULDER
line: Like those folks under the floorboard

speaker: MULDER
line: How did you do that?

speaker: MAURICE
line: I didn't do anything.

speaker: MULDER
line: There were corpses here-- bodies buried under the floorboards.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Why don't you have a seat, son.

speaker: MAURICE
line: You drink? Take drugs?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Get high?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Are you overcome by the impulse to make everyone believe you?

speaker: MAURICE
line: I'm in the field of mental health. I specialize in disorders and manias related to pathological behavior as it pertains to the paranormal.

speaker: MULDER
line: Wow. I didn't know such a thing existed.

speaker: MAURICE
line: My specialty is in what I call soul prospectors-- a crossaxial classification I've codified by extensive interaction with visitors like yourself. I've found you all tend to fall into pretty much the same category.

speaker: MULDER
line: And what category is that?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Narcissistic, overzealous, self-righteous egomaniac.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a category?

speaker: MAURICE
line: You kindly think of yourself as single-minded but you're prone to obsessive compulsiveness workaholism, antisocialism... Fertile fields for the descent into total wacko breakdown.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think that pegs me exactly.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Oh, really? Waving a gun around my house? Huh? Raving like a lunatic about some imaginary brick wall?

speaker: MAURICE
line: You've probably convinced yourself you've seen aliens. You know why you think you see the things you do?

speaker: MULDER
line: Because I have seen them?

speaker: MAURICE
line: 'Cause you're a lonely man. A lonely man chasing paramasturbatory illusions that you believe will give your life meaning and significance and which your pathetic social maladjustment makes impossible for you to find elsewhere. You probably consider yourself passionate, serious, misunderstood. Am I right?

speaker: MULDER
line: "Paramasturbatory"?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Most people would rather stick their fingers in a wall socket than spend a minute with you.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right, now just, uh... Just back off for a second.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Spend every Christmas this way... Alone?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not alone.

speaker: MAURICE
line: More self-delusion.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I came here with my partner. She's somewhere in the house.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Behind a brick wall?

speaker: MAURICE
line: How'd you get her to come with you? Steal her car keys?

speaker: MAURICE
line: You know why you do it-- listen endlessly to her droning rationalizations. 'Cause you're afraid. Afraid of the loneliness. Am I right?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'd just like to find my partner.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Good... Easy. Piece of cake.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Brick wall... Or brick wall? Go ahead, change your life.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: LYDA
line: No, no, please, I won't hurt you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm a federal agent! I'm armed.

speaker: LYDA
line: You're what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm armed.

speaker: LYDA
line: You said...

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm armed.

speaker: LYDA
line: You're a federal agent?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Please, I'm a little on edge. Don't come any closer. My name is Special Agent Dana Scully. And, uh, I can... I can show you my I.D.

speaker: LYDA
line: My goodness, I... I thought you were a ghost.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can assure you that I'm not. I, uh, I got stuck in this room looking for my partner.

speaker: LYDA
line: Oh, the gangly fellow with the distinguished profile.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You've seen him?

speaker: LYDA
line: With you in the foyer. I thought he was a ghost, too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh... That was you.

speaker: LYDA
line: I sleepwalk sometimes. I thought maybe I'd dreamed it. But then here you were again.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I am sorry... I'm sorry. I didn't mean to scare you. I, uh... It's just that we found bodies.

speaker: LYDA
line: Bodies... Where?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Right...

speaker: LYDA
line: You look like you saw a ghost. There are ghosts in this house, you know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who are you?

speaker: LYDA
line: I live here, thank you very much.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where's my partner?

speaker: LYDA
line: Why are you pointing that gun?

speaker: SCULLY
line: There were corpses right there underneath the floor!

speaker: LYDA
line: I think maybe the ghosts have been playing tricks on you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't believe in ghosts.

speaker: LYDA
line: Then what are you doing here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's my partner.

speaker: LYDA
line: He believes in ghosts?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: LYDA
line: Oh, you poor child. You must have an awful small life. Spending your Christmas Eve with him... Running around chasing things you don't even believe in.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't come any closer.

speaker: LYDA
line: I can see it in your face... The fear... The conflicted yearnings... A subconscious desire to find fulfillment through another. Intimacy through co-dependency.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: LYDA
line: Maybe you repress the truth about why you're really here pretending it's out of duty or loyalty-- unable to admit your dirty little secret. Your only joy in life is proving him wrong.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You don't know me. And you don't live here. This isn't your house.

speaker: LYDA
line: You wouldn't think so, the way I'm being treated.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then why is all the furniture covered?

speaker: LYDA
line: We're having the house painted.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well then where's your Christmas tree?!

speaker: LYDA
line: We're Jewish. Boo.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hold it right there. Don't make me shoot you. Stay where you are.

speaker: MAURICE
line: We really attract them, don't we?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where's Mulder?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Mulder? Is that his name?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where is he?

speaker: MAURICE
line: He'll be along.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Move over there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Both of you, move. Move over there. Move other there.

speaker: MAURICE
line: This violates our civil rights. I have friends at the ACLU.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Put your hands up.

speaker: MAURICE
line: You see what we've resorted to? Gimmicks and cheap tricks. We used to be so good at this.

speaker: LYDA
line: We used to have years to drive them mad. Now we get one night.

speaker: MAURICE
line: This pop psychology approach is crap. All it does is annoy them. When's the last time we actually haunted anyone?

speaker: LYDA
line: When was the last time we had a good double murder? Not since the house was condemned.

speaker: MAURICE
line: This is embarrassing-- amateur kid stuff.

speaker: LYDA
line: Look, if we let our reputations slip they're going to take us off the tourist literature. Last year no one even showed up.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Oh, of all days, why did you pick Christmas? Why not Halloween?

speaker: LYDA
line: Now, who is filled with hopelessness and futility on Halloween? Christmas comes but once a year.

speaker: MAURICE
line: You're right. These two do seem pretty miserable. We need to show them just how lonely Christmas can be.

speaker: LYDA
line: Now that's the old Yuletide spirit.

speaker: LYDA
line: Are you Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Who are you, now?

speaker: LYDA
line: What are you doing using my chair for a ladder?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm trying to get out of this room.

speaker: LYDA
line: Trying to get out?

speaker: MULDER
line: Excuse me.

speaker: LYDA
line: No, no. You can't get out that way.

speaker: LYDA
line: Masher.

speaker: MULDER
line: Frump.

speaker: LYDA
line: I don't know who you're calling a frump but I don't appreciate that-- being manhandled, or called names. Certainly not at this hour.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're a ghost.

speaker: LYDA
line: Oh, more names!

speaker: MULDER
line: What happened to the star-crossed lovers?

speaker: LYDA
line: Oh, let me tell you the romance is the first thing to go.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's you. You're Lyda, and that was Maurice. But you've aged.

speaker: LYDA
line: I hope your partner finds you a lot more charming than I do. Let's see. Where is it?

speaker: LYDA
line: No, no, no, no... there it is. I was young and beautiful once, just like your partner. Whoo! Look at us. Maurice was so handsome. He didn't have a gut.

speaker: LYDA
line: I hope you're not expecting any great advantages to all this.

speaker: MULDER
line: To all what?

speaker: LYDA
line: I'm assuming you came here with similar misconceptions.

speaker: MULDER
line: We came here looking for you.

speaker: LYDA
line: Oh, yeah? You didn't come here to be together for eternity?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: LYDA
line: Because you're filled with despair and woeful Christmas melancholy?

speaker: MULDER
line: Why?

speaker: LYDA
line: Maybe it was your partner then.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about her?

speaker: LYDA
line: You knew this house was haunted.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: LYDA
line: Maybe you two should have discussed your real feelings before you came out here. I'm speaking from experience.

speaker: MULDER
line: What experience?

speaker: LYDA
line: I'm not going to get into semantics. A murder-suicide is all about trust.

speaker: MULDER
line: I thought you had a lovers' pact.

speaker: LYDA
line: Poetic illusions aside, the outcome, Mulder, is pretty much the same.

speaker: LYDA
line: I don't show my hole to just anyone.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why are you showing it to me?

speaker: LYDA
line: It isn't like you're going to be eating any Christmas ham, is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, you're trying to tell me that Scully's going to shoot me. Scully is not going to shoot me.

speaker: LYDA
line: Suit yourself, but if you shoot first, for her, the rest is an act of faith.

speaker: MULDER
line: I wouldn't shoot her.

speaker: LYDA
line: Maybe she shoots herself.

speaker: MULDER
line: I wouldn't let her.

speaker: LYDA
line: The bodies under the floor-- maybe that was just some kind of Jungian symbolism. Or maybe... there's a secret lovers' pact.

speaker: MULDER
line: We're not lovers.

speaker: LYDA
line: And this isn't a pure science. But you're both so attractive and there'll be a lot of time to work that out. Go ahead, take it.

speaker: LYDA
line: Take it. Think of it as the last Christmas you'll ever spend alone.

speaker: MAURICE
line: I locked it. For your protection.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Stay away from me. Look, I want you to get me out of here. I am quite capable of pulling this trigger.

speaker: MAURICE
line: I'm glad to hear it. You may well have to defend yourself against that crazy partner of yours.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What have you done with him?!

speaker: MAURICE
line: Kept him safe from his own mad devices-- at least for now. Do you have any idea why he brought you here to this house?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, all I know is this is just some bad dream. This is all in my head.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Yet here you are waving a gun at me like your partner.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully!

speaker: MAURICE
line: Do you realize how seriously disturbed that man is? How dark and lonely? What he's capable of?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MAURICE
line: Want your car keys?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where did you get those?

speaker: MAURICE
line: He's got nowhere to go this Christmas. No one to go with. Did he happen to mention a story about a lovers' pact?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where did you get those keys?

speaker: MAURICE
line: The man is acting out an unconscious yearning. The deep-seated terror of being alone.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully... Scully, are you there?!

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm here, Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Open the door, Scully!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Open the door.

speaker: MAURICE
line: I've seen it happen too many times in this house.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't believe you. Just open the door.

speaker: MAURICE
line: But...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Open the door!

speaker: MULDER
line: Where's Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, what are you doing? Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: There's no getting out of here, Scully. There's no way home.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, come on... Mulder, don't come any closer. You're scaring me. Put the gun down!

speaker: MULDER
line: You going to shoot me?!

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not going to shoot you! I don't want to shoot you!

speaker: MULDER
line: It's me or you... You or me. One of us has to do it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, look... We don't have to do this.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, yes, we do.

speaker: SCULLY
line: We can get out of here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Even if we could what's waiting for us? More loneliness! And then 365 more shopping days till even more loneliness!

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't believe what you're saying! Mulder, I don't believe a word of it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Merry Christmas, Scully.

speaker: LYDA
line: And a happy New Year.

speaker: MULDER/LYDA
line: Let me go!

speaker: LYDA
line: Let me go!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: LYDA
line: Let me go... Let me go...

speaker: MULDER/LYDA
line: Let me go!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... Is that you?

speaker: MULDER
line: What did you do?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I didn't believe it, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: You didn't believe what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I didn't believe that you'd do it... That I would...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Merry Christmas, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you doing?

speaker: MUSIC
line: Have yourself a merry little Christmas Let yourself be light From now on, your troubles will be out of sight Have yourself a merry little Christmas Make the Yuletide gay From now on, our troubles will be miles away Here we are, as in olden days

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully? Happy golden days of yore Faithful friends who are dear to us Gather near to us...

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully... Through the years, we all will be together... Until then, we'll have...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ah... I'm not going to make it.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, you're not... Not without me, you're not.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you afraid, Mulder? I am.

speaker: MULDER
line: I am, too. Faithful friends who are dear to us Gather near to us...

speaker: MULDER
line: You should have thought of this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You should have.

speaker: MULDER
line: You shot me first!

speaker: SCULLY
line: I didn't shoot you. You shot me. If the fates allow Until then we'll have to muddle through somehow...

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully...

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: Get up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can't.

speaker: MULDER
line: Get up... You're not shot.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on. It's a trick. It's all in your head. Faithful friends who are dear to us Gather near to us once more Through the years, we all will be together If the fates allow Hang a shining star upon the highest bough And have yourself a merry... little Christmas now.

speaker: LYDA
line: You hear that? It's Christmas.

speaker: MAURICE
line: One for the books.

speaker: LYDA
line: We almost had those two, didn't we?

speaker: MAURICE
line: Almost had them.

speaker: LYDA
line: Two such lonely souls.

speaker: MAURICE
line: We can't let our failures haunt us.

speaker: LYDA
line: You wonder what they were really out here looking for.

speaker: MAURICE
line: Hard to say. People now... This is just another joyless day of the year.

speaker: LYDA
line: Not for us.

speaker: MAURICE
line: No. We haven't forgotten the meaning of Christmas.

speaker: TV SCROOGE
line: I don't deserve to be so happy. I can't help it. I just can't help it.

speaker: TV NARRATOR
line: Scrooge was better than his word. He became as good a friend, as good a master and as good a man as the good old city ever knew or any other good old city, town or borough in the good old world. And to Tiny Tim...

speaker: SCULLY
line: I, uh... I couldn't sleep. I was, um...

speaker: MULDER
line: Come in. Aren't you supposed to be opening Christmas gifts with your family?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... None of that really happened out there tonight... That was all in our heads, right?

speaker: MULDER
line: I-it must have been.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mmm. Not that, uh, my only joy in life is proving you wrong.

speaker: MULDER
line: When have you proved me wrong?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well... Why else would you want me out there with you?

speaker: MULDER
line: You didn't want to be there?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, that's, um... That's self-righteous and... narcissistic of me to say, isn't it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I mean... Maybe I did want to be out there with you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now, um... I know we said that we weren't going to exchange gifts but, uh... I got you... a little something.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: MULDER
line: Merry Christmas.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I got you a little something, too.

speaker: BING CROSBY
line: Have yourself a merry little Christmas now.
